title: Psalms Chapter 66 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 66 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 66 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 66.

questions.question: What does Psalms 66:1 ask all lands to do to God?
questions.correctAnswer: Make a joyful noise
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:1 instructs all lands to 'Make a joyful noise unto God.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 66:3, what will the enemies do through the greatness of God's power?
questions.correctAnswer: Submit themselves unto God
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:3 says that through God's great power, His enemies shall submit themselves unto Him.

questions.question: What did God turn into dry land as mentioned in Psalms 66:6?
questions.correctAnswer: The sea
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:6 states that God turned the sea into dry land.

questions.question: In Psalms 66:7, what does God do forever by His power?
questions.correctAnswer: He ruleth
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:7 tells us that God ruleth by His power forever.

questions.question: What does Psalms 66:9 say God holds in life?
questions.correctAnswer: Our soul
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:9 states that God holds our soul in life.

questions.question: According to Psalms 66:10, God has proved and tried us as what is tried?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:10 compares God's testing of us to the testing of silver.

questions.question: What kind of offerings does the psalmist vow to offer in Psalms 66:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt offerings
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:13 mentions going into God's house with burnt offerings and paying vows.

questions.question: What will the psalmist offer with the burnt sacrifices according to Psalms 66:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Incense of rams
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:15 says the psalmist will offer burnt sacrifices with the incense of rams.

questions.question: Who is invited to come and hear in Psalms 66:16?
options: All the kings of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: All ye that fear God
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:16 invites 'all ye that fear God' to come and hear what He has done.

questions.question: According to Psalms 66:18, what will cause the Lord not to hear the psalmist?
options: If I regard iniquity in my heart
questions.correctAnswer: If I regard iniquity in my heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:18 warns that if the psalmist regards iniquity in his heart, the Lord will not hear him.

questions.question: What has God not turned away from the psalmist according to Psalms 66:20?
questions.correctAnswer: His prayer and mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:20 blesses God because He has not turned away the psalmist's prayer nor His mercy.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 66:4 says all the earth shall worship God and sing to His name.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:4 clearly states that all the earth shall worship and sing to God's name.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 66:12 mentions that God brought the people through fire and water into a wealthy place.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:12 describes going through fire and water and God bringing them into a wealthy place.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 66:17 describes crying unto God with the mouth and God ignoring the prayer.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:17 says the psalmist cried unto God and He was extolled; God did listen.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 66:14: 'Which my lips have uttered, and my mouth hath _____, when I was in trouble.'
questions.correctAnswer: spoken
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:14 states that the psalmist's mouth hath spoken when in trouble.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 66 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 66 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 66, what biblical truth would you share about God's role in trials?
options: God tests and refines us like silver to strengthen our faith
God abandons us in our trials to teach independence
Trials are punishment without any purpose
God ignores our prayers during difficulties
questions.correctAnswer: God tests and refines us like silver to strengthen our faith
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:10 says God has proved and tried us as silver is tried, showing that trials serve to refine and strengthen us. Verses 11 and 12 describe going through affliction and fire, but God brings us to a prosperous place, indicating His purpose in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 66 teach us about the importance of praising God in daily life?
options: We should make a joyful noise and sing praises to God continually
Praising God is only necessary during worship services
Praise is optional and not important in the believer’s life
Praise should be silent and private only
questions.correctAnswer: We should make a joyful noise and sing praises to God continually
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 command all lands to make a joyful noise and sing forth the honor of God's name. Verse 8 encourages the people to bless God and make the voice of His praise heard, emphasizing continual praise in life.

questions.question: A believer wants to share a testimony of God's deliverance. According to Psalms 66, what is a good approach to encourage others?
options: Invite others to hear what God has done for your soul
Focus on others’ failures rather than God’s work
questions.correctAnswer: Invite others to hear what God has done for your soul
questions.explanation: Verse 16 invites those who fear God to come and hear the declaration of what He has done for the psalmist’s soul, showing the value of sharing testimonies to encourage faith and trust.

questions.question: How does Psalms 66 teach about trust in God during adversity?
options: Trust God to keep our souls alive and prevent us from stumbling
Rely solely on human strength to overcome troubles
Believe God has forgotten us during affliction
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to keep our souls alive and prevent us from stumbling
questions.explanation: Verse 9 says God holds our soul in life and does not allow our feet to be moved, encouraging trust in God’s sustaining power during adversity. Verses 17-19 confirm that God hears the cries of those who call on Him in trouble.

questions.question: What lesson about obedience and keeping a pure heart can be drawn from Psalms 66?
options: If we hold sin in our hearts, God will not hear our prayers
God hears prayers regardless of our heart condition
Sin in the heart has no effect on prayer
We can pray only with words, not heart purity
questions.correctAnswer: If we hold sin in our hearts, God will not hear our prayers
questions.explanation: Verse 18 warns that if iniquity is regarded in the heart, the Lord will not hear, teaching the importance of repentance and holiness in prayer life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 66, God’s eyes behold all nations and He rules forever by His power.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that God rules by His power forever and His eyes behold the nations, affirming His sovereign authority and vigilance over all peoples.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with gratitude. Based on Psalms 66, what encouragement would you offer about remembering God's mercy?
options: Bless God who has not turned away our prayers nor His mercy
Forget past mercies and focus only on current blessings
Doubt God’s mercy when prayers seem unanswered
Rely on self rather than God's mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Bless God who has not turned away our prayers nor His mercy
questions.explanation: Verse 20 blesses God who has not turned away the psalmist’s prayer or His mercy, encouraging believers to remember and be thankful for God’s faithful mercy and answer to prayer.

questions.question: How does Psalms 66 encourage integrity and fulfilling vows to God?
options: We should faithfully go to God's house and pay vows with offerings
Vows to God can be neglected when convenient
Words alone are enough without action
Vows are unnecessary in Christian life
questions.correctAnswer: We should faithfully go to God's house and pay vows with offerings
questions.explanation: Verses 13-15 express the psalmist’s commitment to go into God’s house with burnt offerings and fulfill vows made during trouble, emphasizing integrity and faithfulness in devotion.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 66 teaches that all the earth will worship God and sing to His name.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 4 declares that all the earth shall worship God and sing to His name, highlighting the universal scope of worship due to God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 66 illustrate God’s power in His works towards mankind?
options: God’s works are terrible and cause enemies to submit
God’s power is weak and ineffective
God ignores the children of men
God’s works are secret and unknown
questions.correctAnswer: God’s works are terrible and cause enemies to submit
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 5 describe God’s works as terrible and powerful, causing enemies to submit and showing His awe-inspiring strength toward humanity.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance through trials does Psalms 66 provide?
options: Through fire and water, God brings us into a prosperous place
Trials will always end in destruction
Trials are pointless and should be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: Through fire and water, God brings us into a prosperous place
questions.explanation: Verse 12 says the psalmist went through fire and water but God brought them into a wealthy place, teaching perseverance and trust that God will deliver through trials.

questions.question: A believer is learning about evangelism. Based on Psalms 66, what approach about sharing God’s greatness would you recommend?
options: Invite all people to come and see the works of God
Keep God’s works private and personal
Only tell close family about God’s deeds
Avoid discussing God’s power with others
questions.correctAnswer: Invite all people to come and see the works of God
questions.explanation: Verse 5 invites all to come and see the works of God, encouraging open proclamation of God’s mighty deeds as part of evangelism and witness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "I cried unto him with my mouth, and he was extolled with my ____."
questions.correctAnswer: tongue
questions.explanation: Verse 17 says the psalmist cried out with his mouth and extolled God with his tongue, emphasizing vocal praise and prayer.

questions.question: How does Psalms 66 describe God's protection over His people?
options: He holds our soul in life and keeps our feet from slipping
He leaves us alone to fend for ourselves
He is indifferent to human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: He holds our soul in life and keeps our feet from slipping
questions.explanation: Verse 9 highlights God's sustaining care, holding our soul in life and not allowing our feet to be moved, teaching believers to trust in His protection.

questions.question: What does Psalms 66 teach about the importance of honest and sincere prayer?
options: God hears and attends to sincere prayers when the heart is pure
God ignores prayers no matter their sincerity
Prayers are only effective if said in a crowd
questions.correctAnswer: God hears and attends to sincere prayers when the heart is pure
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 teach that if sin is held in the heart, God does not hear, but He truly hears and attends to the voice of sincere prayer, emphasizing honesty and purity in prayer life.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 66 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 66.

questions.question: In Psalms 66:6, what miraculous event is described that recalls the Exodus narrative?
options: He turned the sea into dry land
He caused manna to fall from heaven
questions.correctAnswer: He turned the sea into dry land
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:6 refers to God turning the sea into dry land, an allusion to the crossing of the Red Sea during the Exodus (Exodus 14), highlighting God's power to save His people.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Psalms 66:3, where God’s works are described as 'terrible' and enemies submit?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:3 uses parallelism, a common Hebrew poetry device, contrasting God's terrifying works with the submission of enemies to emphasize His sovereign power.

questions.question: According to Psalms 66:10, what analogy is used to describe how God tests His people?
options: As gold is refined in fire
questions.correctAnswer: As silver is tried
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states God has tried the people 'as silver is tried,' indicating a purification process akin to refining precious metals (Psalms 66:10).

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 66:9 emphasizes God’s sustaining power over life and stability?
options: "He turned the sea into dry land"
questions.correctAnswer: "Which holdeth our soul in life"
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:9 highlights God’s sustaining power by stating He 'holdeth our soul in life,' indicating divine preservation and stability.

questions.question: What does the term 'Selah' likely indicate in Psalms 66:4 and 15?
questions.correctAnswer: A musical pause or reflection
questions.explanation: 'Selah' is generally understood as a liturgical or musical pause, inviting reflection on the preceding words, as seen in Psalms 66:4 and 15.

questions.question: In Psalms 66:12, the phrase 'we went through fire and through water' symbolizes what in ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: Trial and deliverance
questions.explanation: The phrase symbolizes severe trials and God’s deliverance, common motifs in the Hebrew Bible representing purification through adversity (Psalms 66:12).

questions.question: Psalms 66:18 warns that if one regards iniquity in their heart, what will be the consequence?
options: They will be cast out of the assembly
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord will not hear
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that if iniquity is regarded in the heart, the Lord will not hear the prayer, emphasizing purity of heart (Psalms 66:18).

questions.question: What type of offering does the psalmist vow to bring in Psalms 66:13-15?
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt offerings and sacrifices
questions.explanation: The psalmist promises burnt offerings and sacrifices of fatlings, rams, bullocks, and goats, indicating a full sacrificial dedication (Psalms 66:13-15).

questions.question: Which theme prevalent in Psalms 66 is echoed in New Testament passages such as Acts 16:25-34, where praise is offered in trials?
options: Praise in the midst of deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: Praise in the midst of deliverance
questions.explanation: The theme of praising God through trials and deliverance, as seen in Psalms 66, is mirrored in Acts 16 where Paul and Silas praise God despite imprisonment.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 66:7 emphasizes that God’s rule is temporary and limited.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:7 declares that God 'ruleth by his power forever,' indicating an eternal and sovereign rule.

questions.question: The phrase 'Thou broughtest us into the net' in Psalms 66:11 can be interpreted as which of the following in the ancient Near Eastern covenant context?
options: A metaphor for divine testing or affliction
A description of a hunting scene
questions.correctAnswer: A metaphor for divine testing or affliction
questions.explanation: The 'net' metaphor commonly represents entrapment or affliction by enemies or trials allowed by God to test His people (Psalms 66:11).

questions.question: In Psalms 66:16, who is invited to 'come and hear,' and what is the significance of this audience?
options: All who fear God; indicating a community of reverent worshipers
The priests only; focusing on temple worship
The kings of the earth; emphasizing political authority
questions.correctAnswer: All who fear God; indicating a community of reverent worshipers
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls 'all ye that fear God' to listen, highlighting an audience of faithful worshipers who revere God (Psalms 66:16).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the overall structural movement of Psalms 66?
options: Call to praise, recounting of God’s mighty acts, testimony of deliverance, vow of thanksgiving
Lament over enemies, plea for mercy, promise of vengeance, hymn of praise
Description of creation, covenant renewal, prophetic warning, final blessing
Historical narrative, legal code, wisdom sayings, prophetic oracle
questions.correctAnswer: Call to praise, recounting of God’s mighty acts, testimony of deliverance, vow of thanksgiving
questions.explanation: The Psalm progresses from inviting all lands to praise, recounts God’s mighty deeds, personal testimony of trials and deliverance, and concludes with vows of thanks (Psalms 66:1-20).

questions.question: How does Psalms 66:19-20 illustrate the concept of God's mercy in the context of answered prayer?
options: God has attended to the prayer and not turned away mercy
God requires constant sacrifice before answering
God's mercy is limited to Israel only
God answers only when there is no sin at all
questions.correctAnswer: God has attended to the prayer and not turned away mercy
questions.explanation: The verses affirm that God heard the prayer and did not withdraw mercy, highlighting the faithful nature of God's response (Psalms 66:19-20).

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist in Psalms 66 expresses confidence that God’s eyes behold the nations, implying divine surveillance over all peoples.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:7 explicitly states that God’s eyes behold the nations, affirming His sovereign oversight.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 66 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 66 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 66, what is the primary reason the psalmist calls all the earth to make a joyful noise unto God?
options: Because of God's terrible works and power
Because of the covenant with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because of God's terrible works and power
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:1-3 call all lands to praise God because of His terrible works and great power, which cause even His enemies to submit. This reveals God's sovereignty and mighty acts. Similarly, Exodus 15:11 praises God's fearful deeds, and Romans 1:20 acknowledges God's power revealed in creation.

questions.question: What does the psalmist invite the hearers to do in verse 5 of Psalms 66?
options: Come and see the works of God
Sing a new song to the Lord
Pray for the forgiveness of sins
questions.correctAnswer: Come and see the works of God
questions.explanation: In Psalms 66:5, the psalmist invites the people to ‘come and see the works of God,’ emphasizing that God's mighty acts toward humanity are awe-inspiring. This aligns with biblical themes in Isaiah 40:26 and John 3:21 where God's works are to be witnessed and glorified.

questions.question: What does Psalms 66:6 describe as an example of God's mighty deeds?
options: Turning the sea into dry land
questions.correctAnswer: Turning the sea into dry land
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:6 refers to God turning the sea into dry land, a clear allusion to the Exodus event where God parted the Red Sea (Exodus 14:21-22). This act demonstrates God's power to save and lead His people, consistent with references in 2 Corinthians 1:10 and Hebrews 11:29.

questions.question: How does Psalms 66:7 describe God's rule over nations?
options: He rules by His power forever and watches over the nations
He allows nations to rule themselves independently
questions.correctAnswer: He rules by His power forever and watches over the nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:7 states that God rules by His power forever and His eyes behold the nations, indicating His eternal sovereignty and providential oversight. This corresponds with Daniel 4:35, Psalm 22:28, and Revelation 19:6 affirming God’s universal and everlasting reign.

questions.question: What is the psalmist's response to God's protection and deliverance as expressed in Psalms 66:9?
options: God holds our soul in life and does not allow our feet to be moved
God punishes us for our sins
God remains silent in times of trouble
God leaves us to our own devices
questions.correctAnswer: God holds our soul in life and does not allow our feet to be moved
questions.explanation: In Psalms 66:9, the psalmist praises God for preserving life and stability, highlighting God's sustaining grace. This theme is echoed in Deuteronomy 33:27, Psalm 37:24, and Philippians 1:6, showing God’s faithfulness to sustain His people.

questions.question: According to Psalms 66:10-12, what metaphor does the psalmist use to describe the testing and affliction experienced?
options: Silver being tried and affliction as a net
A tree being rooted and storms
A furnace of fire and refining gold
A shepherd leading sheep through valleys
questions.correctAnswer: Silver being tried and affliction as a net
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:10-12 uses the metaphor of silver being tried to illustrate God's testing, and describes affliction as being caught in a net, ridden over, and passing through fire and water. This reflects themes of divine refinement and discipline found in Job 23:10, Isaiah 48:10, and 1 Peter 1:6-7.

questions.question: What vow does the psalmist declare in Psalms 66:13-15 as a response to God's deliverance?
options: To go into God’s house with burnt offerings and pay vows
To build a temple for God
To proclaim God's word to all nations
questions.correctAnswer: To go into God’s house with burnt offerings and pay vows
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:13-15 shows the psalmist’s commitment to offer burnt sacrifices and fulfill vows as thanksgiving for God's deliverance, consistent with the biblical practice of covenantal worship seen in Leviticus 1:3, Psalm 50:14, and Hebrews 13:15.

questions.question: In Psalms 66:16, who does the psalmist call to listen and hear his declaration?
questions.correctAnswer: All who fear God
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls 'all ye that fear God' to hear his testimony of God's deeds (Psalms 66:16). This highlights the community of the faithful who reverence God, paralleling reverence themes in Psalm 115:11, Proverbs 1:7, and Acts 10:35.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about the Lord's response to his prayers in Psalms 66:19-20?
options: God has heard and not turned away his prayer
God tests his faith by silence
God ignores the prayers of the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God has heard and not turned away his prayer
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:19-20 affirm that God has heard the psalmist’s prayer and shown mercy, reflecting a doctrine of God’s attentiveness to the prayers of His people, consistent with 1 John 5:14, Jeremiah 29:12, and Matthew 7:7.

questions.question: What condition does the psalmist acknowledge affects God's hearing of prayer in Psalms 66:18?
options: If I regard iniquity in my heart, the Lord will not hear me
If I pray with fasting and tears
If I speak aloud in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: If I regard iniquity in my heart, the Lord will not hear me
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:18 states that harboring sin in the heart hinders prayer from being heard, highlighting the necessity of repentance, a principle echoed in Isaiah 59:2, Proverbs 28:9, and 1 Peter 3:12.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the theological theme of God's power and mercy in Psalms 66?
options: God’s mighty works demonstrate His sovereignty, and His mercy sustains and delivers His people
God is distant and only punishes the wicked
God’s power is limited to Israel only
God’s mercy is conditional upon sacrifices alone
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mighty works demonstrate His sovereignty, and His mercy sustains and delivers His people
questions.explanation: The psalm consistently portrays God as sovereign in power (Psalms 66:3,7) and merciful in sustaining and delivering His people (Psalms 66:9,12,20). This dual emphasis is found throughout Scripture (Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 103:8, Romans 11:33-36).

questions.question: How does Psalms 66 relate to the doctrine of salvation history as seen in the Old Testament?
options: It recalls God's mighty acts like the Exodus to affirm His saving power
It focuses exclusively on future eschatology
It centers on temple rituals without historical reference
It denies God's involvement in worldly affairs
questions.correctAnswer: It recalls God's mighty acts like the Exodus to affirm His saving power
questions.explanation: The psalm recalls God’s deliverance through the Red Sea (Psalms 66:6) and trials, linking to salvation history themes in the Old Testament such as Exodus 14 and Numbers 21, emphasizing God’s active salvation work.

questions.question: What Christological insight can be drawn from the psalmist’s testimony of deliverance and answered prayer in Psalms 66?
options: It anticipates Christ as the ultimate deliverer and intercessor
It rejects the need for a mediator
It focuses solely on human effort for salvation
It denies God’s involvement in human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates Christ as the ultimate deliverer and intercessor
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s experience of deliverance and God hearing prayer (Psalms 66:17,19) prefigures Christ’s role as mediator who delivers from sin and intercedes (Hebrews 7:25, Romans 8:34), fulfilling the hope expressed.

questions.question: In Psalms 66, what does the call to 'bless our God, ye people' in verse 8 reveal about the role of the community in worship?
options: Worship is a communal act that proclaims God’s praises publicly
Worship is an individual, private act
Worship requires silence rather than vocal praise
questions.correctAnswer: Worship is a communal act that proclaims God’s praises publicly
questions.explanation: Psalms 66:8 invites the people collectively to bless God and make His praise heard, emphasizing corporate worship consistent with themes in Psalm 95:1-7 and Hebrews 10:24-25.

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s justice and rebellion is taught in Psalms 66:7?
options: God’s power rules eternally and rebellious peoples will not prevail
God ignores rebellion and allows it to triumph
God punishes only individuals, not nations
God’s justice is limited to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power rules eternally and rebellious peoples will not prevail
questions.explanation: Verse 7 teaches that God’s eternal rule ensures that rebellious people cannot exalt themselves, highlighting divine justice and sovereignty. This is consistent with Isaiah 14:27, Romans 13:1, and Psalm 2:1-4.
